contentrichtext.text: {{Infobox website | name = Meetup | logo = | screenshot = | caption = | url = [http://www.meetup.com/ meetup.com] | commercial = Yes | type = [[Social networking]] | language = [[English language|English]], Spanish, German, French, Italian, Portuguese | registration = | owner = Meetup Inc. | author = | launch date = 2001 | current status = | revenue = | slogan = | alexa = {{DecreasePositive}} 467 ({{as of|2012|8|2|alt=August 2012}})<ref name="alexa">{{cite web|url= http://www.alexa.com/siteinfo/meetup.com |title= Meetup.com Site Info | publisher= [[Alexa Internet]] |accessdate= 2012-08-02 }}</ref><!--Updated monthly by OKBot.--> }} '''Meetup''' is an online [[social networking]] portal that facilitates offline group meetings in various localities around the world. Meetup allows members to find and join groups unified by a common interest, such as politics, books, games, movies, health, pets, careers or hobbies. Users enter their ZIP code or their city and the topic they want to meet about, and the website helps them arrange a place and time to meet. Topic listings are also available for users who only enter a location. Meetup receives revenue by charging Organizer Dues to administrators of groups, currently at $12 to $19 per month depending on the payment plan. Following the [[September 11 attacks]], the site's co-founder [[Scott Heiferman]] publicly stated that the manner in which people in [[New York City]] came together in the aftermath of that traumatic event inspired him to use the Internet to make it easier for people to connect with strangers in their community.<ref>Celia Sankar, "[http://celiasankar.com/blog/2011/11/16/meetup-ceo-talks-about-doing-what-you-love/ Meetup CEO talks about doing what you love]," November 16, 2011.</ref> Meetup, Inc. is based in [[New York City]]. ==Statistics== As of April 2013, the company claimed to have 13.4 million members in 196 countries and 125,247 groups,<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.meetup.com/about/ |title=About |publisher=Meetup |date= |accessdate=2013-06-16}}</ref> although these figures may include inactive members and groups. == See also == * [[Federated Media]]'s BigTent Groups * [[Google Groups]] * [[GroupSpaces]] * [[Ning (website)]] * [[SocialGO]] * [[Wall.fm]] * [[Tiki Wiki CMS Groupware]] * [[Yahoo! Groups]] * [[Virtual community]] * [https://www.hourworld.org/ hOurWorld] == References == {{Refimprove|date=January 2011}} {{Reflist}} == External links == {{wiktionary|Meetup}} * {{Official website|http://www.meetup.com/}} * Jim Cashel, "[http://www.onlinecommunityreport.com/2002/08/interview-with-scott-heiferman-meetup/ Interview with Scott Heiferman, MEETUP]{{dead link|date=March 2013}}," Online Community Report, August 2002. * Debera Carlton Harrell, "[http://press.meetup.com/archives/000067.html Meetup.com Links Together the Like-minded]," ''Seattle Post-Intelligencer'', March 8, 2003. * Chris Gray, "MeetUp.com Working to Become a Force in Politics," Knight Ridder, February 8, 2004. * Nathan Kaiser, "[http://www.npost.com/blog/2004/04/20/interview-with-scott-heiferman-ceo-of-meetup/ Interview with Scott Heiferman]," nPost, April 20, 2004. * "[http://www.meetup.com/organize/pages/Interview_with_Scott_Heiferman_-_Our_First_Event%21/ Video with Interview with Meetup Founder & CEO Scott Heiferman]", explaining Meetup.com´s mission – The Meetup Organizer Boot Camp, June 10, 2009 [[Category:Politics and technology]] [[Category:Social networking services]] [[Category:Internet-based activism]] [[Category:Technology in society]] [[Category:Social planning websites]] [[Category:Internet properties established in 2001]] [[Category:Companies based in New York City]]
